item.title: Arthrogryposis Multiplex Congenita - NORD (National Organization for Rare Disorders)
item.description:
Arthrogryposis Multiplex Congenita - NORD (National Organization for Rare Disorders)

The most common universal symptom of AMC is limited or absent movement around small and large joints (contractures). The contractures are present at birth (congenital). The muscles of the affected limbs may be underdeveloped (hypoplastic), resulting in a tube-shaped limb with a soft, doughy feeling. Soft tissue webbing may develop over the affected joints.

item.title: Arthrogryposis
item.description:
Arthrogryposis

Arthrogryposis multiplex congenita (AMC), or simply arthrogryposis, describes congenital joint contractures in two or more areas of the body. It derives its name from Greek, literally meaning "curving of joints" ( arthron, "joint"; grȳpōsis, late Latin form of late Greek grūpōsis, "hooking").

item.title: Arthrogryposis
item.description:
Arthrogryposis

Arthrogryposis (arth-ro-grip-OH-sis) means a child is born with joint contractures. This means some of their joints don't move as much as normal and may even be stuck in one position. Often the muscles around these joints are thin, weak, stiff or missing. Extra tissue may have formed around the joints, holding them in place.
